TextView.android:text: Wi-fi networks are often made up of multiple access points, the physical hardware your phone uses to access the internet. They usually look something like this:
Your phone typically doesn't account for traffic when it chooses an access point, only signal strength, so in places like libraries, too much burden tends to fall on a few access points.

This application lets you override that choice based on your experience on that network. The signal strength is certainly a factor, but it's a very fickle thing to measure. Small differences in signal strength shouldn't perceptibly impact your experience. Signal strength is given as a number between 1 and 10.
SSID: This is the name of the overall network, the same as the name you see when you choose a Wi-Fi network through your default OS.
BSSID: This is a name you don't see, the unique name of the physical access point connection you're using. Unlike your OS, this app lets you choose between these to optimize performance.
